@BohoinChicago @AmberLily ...a distinction made between official checkmarks and paid checkmarks. When you click on a checkmark, it'll tell you whether the person is actually verified or just a Twitter Blue subscriber.

@BohoinChicago @AmberLily Now though, for those of us that care about people actually seeing our tweets, it might actually be worth a try. Concerning the checkmark, obviously it has some kinks to be worked out, this whole thing is still in beta for what it's worth. In any case, there's already...

@BohoinChicago @AmberLily For some context, Twitter Blue has been around for a while, long before Elon Musk took over. It's not the only premium option Twitter offers, but it's basically the main option for Twitter Premium or Twitter Pro, if you like. Previously, the Twitter Blue features weren't great.
@AmberLily Last time it was the Twitter redesign and people will be freaking out about something else soon enough.

...the mathematician sitting in the room, solving equations. All things are bound by common sense, physics, and most things are done in a room, which is just a box. I understand the box. Why don't most people understand the box? üò¢

I'm not that smart. What I am, is aware. Most people seem to lack self-awareness or awareness of their surroundings. No matter how "complicated" something is, it still needs to be done in a room with 4 walls, a floor, and a roof. I don't need to understand math to understand...

I'm not going to fact check any of this, and I'm sure that I missed a bunch, and obviously I don't really understand how complicated it must be, but I'm confident in my ability to understand the basic outline/structure of a thing based on, oh, I don't know, existing?

From basic observation, I know that this world is full of all kinds of people and there are many variations in genetics, diseases, etc. That's probably a lot of DNA samples they'd need to get. That and probably limitations in technology is why it's taken so long to map it.

I would imagine that in the beginning, they would need to literally take samples by actually taking blood and even cutting off tiny pieces of flesh from lots of humans and then analyze them under a microscope and somehow record the data and get it onto a computer to research.

Using nothing more than my stupid brain, without knowing any of the actual technical terms or procedures or looking anything up, I can probably manage to create a reasonable outline. Genome, genes, DNA, right? Remember those squiggly lines from Jurassic Park? Dino DNA! Well...

For example, I don't know much about science in the academic sense. I have no science education, training, experience, or understanding of the field any more than the average person, but a headline I read recently was that they finally finished mapping the human genome.
...basic outline or structure of a thing no matter how esoteric using nothing more than basic common sense. So many people seem to lack this, or maybe they're just lazy. I don't get it.

The next time you assume someone is wrong merely because they've gone against the crowd or because the crowd has gone against them ("ratioed"), take a closer look. History is full of people with unpopular opinions, which were later *eventually* adopted as popular opinion.

That means that in real life or online, if you come across two people arguing, the loudest and most confident person may in fact be the dumber of the two. The movie 12 Angry Men is an excellent representation of this dilemma in society.

In other words, 2/3 of people are either of below or average intelligence, while only 1/3 are above ("smart").

To make matters even worse, because of the Dunning-Kruger effect, dumb people tend to overestimate their abilities, while smart people actually underestimate theirs.

Most people aren't dumb, but most people aren't smart either.

That probably sounds like a riddle; it's not; it's a fact. The best way to understand this is to think of it as a spectrum of intelligence:

33.3% (below) | 33.3% (average) | 33.3% (above) https://t.co/18xXNmydHO

I can handle backlash; I have a lot of practice. But, if I'm not able to also have intelligent communication and reach any kind of understanding, what's the point? Censorship wins in the end because speech has been dismantled and no longer seems to have any power or respect.

I try so hard to enter every discussion with a good faith intention of learning and kindness, but the moment I say something someone doesn't like, they don't politely disagree, they go on the attack with downvoting, name-calling, trying to censor me, etc.

But, to me, a safe space would be somewhere where free speech is honored and where we're not afraid to be wrong or ask uncomfortable questions and where if someone disagrees with you, it doesn't make them your enemy.

This might sound hyperbolic, but I'm dead serious. Where? Somewhere online, with friends or family, colleges, bars, where? When we talk about safe spaces, we're actually talking about a place where you have to walk on eggshells and self-censor out of fear of hurting feelings.
Is there any place left on this planet to have civil discourse?

What? Fuck. Obviously we're all going to die, but it never stops being an unwelcome surprise.

Outside of that, if you're thinking "But why are so many people dying in clusters?" I think there probably is something to that concerning generation, life cycle, the environment, etc. https://t.co/uDk5jgWeQi

People claim to respect free speech and to allow for open, safe discussion, but the moment you say something or ask a question they don't like, no matter how carefully and politely you've articulated your words, they're quick to shut you down.

@WillyO4Life I would say an upvote is probably thoughtful 7/10 times, where as a downvote is probably thoughtful 1/10 times. That's the problem; they're not used with equal consideration or fairness.

@WillyO4Life Give a monkey a poo-flinging button, better yet, an anonymous poo-flinging button, and watch them push it as many times as they can for the most ridiculously absurd reasons, including just for fun, even if they don't actually have anything against what they're downvoting.

@WillyO4Life In fact, it's so common, it's most likely cognitive bias (https://t.co/udWO0y8ev2 ‚Äî I'm too lazy to look right now). The idea is simple, if someone likes something, they're generally not that motivated to go out of their way and praise it. However, if they hate something, !!!!!!

@WillyO4Life It's a matter of psychology. For example, I have seen maybe once or twice where a fan went through and blindly upvoted everything someone posted. As opposed to someone who hates someone and blindly goes through, downvoting everything they've posted, which I see daily.

@WillyO4Life In theory, yes. But, in practice, no. I suppose you could then argue well "liking" something, too, could be abused, but it's not the same. Also, the pros and cons may vary on different platforms. I will say, this is a more thoughtful approach than downvoting on Reddit at least.

The amount of wild characters and scenarios to explore goes as far as the imagination can take it, and it would probably be better as a TV series. Kilmer is one of the last to carry the Sawyer name, but the network goes much deeper than just one family.

The story takes place from the perspective of the killers, not the victims, and their only real enemy is defectors of the family, those that are so untamable that they don't follow orders, and maybe other syndicates, but not even the military interferes with them.

The underground network of killers is literally connected by an underground network of tunnels. They've even managed to build their own secret subway system in major areas. It's not a cult; it's a business, a business that is so powerful, it has a foot in every industry.

Kilmer's character likes to keep himself and his home clean, to an OCD level. He loves to watch, but if you get even so much as a drop of blood on him, he'll throw a fit. He's kind of like the mayor, and on the mantle over his fireplace, you can see the "Saw is Family" chainsaw.

Movies 1-4 were all canon and Chop Top makes a return as well as several other cameos. Leatherface is dead (sorry), but he has a whole bastard litter of children from women he raped. Like a new family dog, the family continues to anoint a new Leatherface when the previous dies.

I dreamt last night that Val Kilmer made a return to the big screen in a new, epic Texas Chainsaw Massacre film.

He was the leader, not of a family, not of a crew, but of an entire town of killers, which itself is part of a worldwide network of killers, assassins, and "other." https://t.co/jW1SE0yB4k

How 'bout yours?

When you post something publicly, there's an unwritten social contract that you agree to. You accept that people will agree, disagree, share anecdotes, provide advice, be rude, be weird, etc. You're still human and it sucks when people are rude, but you own that all bets are off.

With friends and family, it's important to let them know how you feel, whether you'd like them to not bring up certain subjects, and even curate what kind of responses you'd like from them. For the public, it's ridiculous to expect or even try to moderate this (within reason).

There are different rules for public communication than there are for private communication.

(please see full thread before voting)

This isn't some new age, hippy way of thinking. I don't belong to any organization with any kind of agenda. This isn't about politics or religion. I am simply a human being on this planet and have enough common sense to recognize that everyone is capable of love and kindness. üß°

There's no such thing. There are good people and bad people everywhere on our planet. There's no such thing as an evil country. Governments, militaries, religions, etc. have committed all kinds of atrocities in the name of whatever, but it doesn't actually represent the people.

It all comes from merely being different than another human being, in belief or appearance or biology. Fear of the other. But, then thousands of years of war and culture and literature and propaganda perpetuate these narratives of other people and countries being "bad."

We live on this side of the street and they, the "others," live on that side of the street. Since we're good (obviously), that must mean that they're bad. Meanwhile, the people on the other side are thinking the exact same thing. This is the root of it at every scale.

Do you know what racism, sexism, classism, ageism, nationalism, or any other kind of ism is? It's a child's game. It's psychology 101: us and them.

There is no substance to any of it. It's literally (in most cases) nothing more than a difference in geography. It's make-believe. https://t.co/Nn6el4rNAg

@octobergeek I'm always curious about everything, but I've gone down a major rabbit hole concerning legal rights recently. ü§ì
@octobergeek Unless you've obviously committed a crime, just about everything a cop asks you is simply a question (not a demand), which you have no obligation to answer.

@octobergeek It goes on the list because it's something so obvious, that should be common sense, but it's not. The reason it's not common sense is because every interaction everyone's ever had with police, they mislead or straight up lied to us about our rights.

@octobergeek Half the states have no statute at all, and the other half have something called stop and identify, which requires that they have suspicion of a crime.

So, for the most part, no matter where you live, if you're just minding your own business, you do not need to ID.

@BohoinChicago Definitely depends on all the elements, who, what where, when, why. Some people ask to be nice, some ask to fill awkward silence, some ask to size you up. If I think someone's nice, I'll be more friendly. If I get any snobby feelings, dishwasher it is.

@BohoinChicago If I told them the real answer, they might be impressed, but their eyes would probably glaze over anyway. I prefer to just tell them that I'm a dishwasher. No disrespect to dishwashers. I actually was one when I was a kid. But, for fancy dinner party people, it shuts 'em up.

@BohoinChicago For strangers though, I like to just make stuff up for fun. Like the classic "What do you do for a living?" I hate small talk, but usually that question is more sinister. Usually, it means "Will you impress me or will I look down on you?"

@BohoinChicago Trying to really explain is an impossible task, but I don't like sarcasm or to shut people down (except for strangers). I try to be an open book, but I've started to try and be more like a picture book and give as dumbed-down an answer as I think most people can swallow.

Every decision we make to give ourselves something is the decision to take it away from somebody else. I'm not even saying it's wrong, it's natural. It's how virtually everyone actually is, but most pretend to be something else.

2. When we go to the grocery store to buy the bread, what do we do? We reach behind the front loaves, to find the freshest ones. Why? Because we always want the best for ourselves. Fuck the other customers. Fuck the grocery store. Fuck the environment.

1. The grocery store that sells the bread hides the freshest loaves behind the oldest ones. Why? For the sake of eliminating food waste for people or the environment? No, for the bottom line, money. Fuck the customers. Fuck the environment.

We all think we're kind with our words, but if actions speak louder than words, aren't we really just telling everyone else to "fuck off" every single day?

...knowing and experiencing are two different things. And sometimes you have to experience something many times before you finally learn the lesson it was trying to teach you.

The lesson is that trying to convince someone who's already decided you're bad or did something wrong is a futile effort. And the harder you try, the more you'll just prove to them that you are what they think you are. I already knew this, intellectually, but...

It's been many years since I cared if people thought I was weird or didn't like me. I got pretty good at dealing with criticism too, but one thing that still gets my goat is when people question my integrity. If they call me a liar, bigot, or think I'm bad or did something wrong.

I've come a looooooooong way in my time on earth so far in terms of improving my understanding of psychology, controlling my temperament, and improving my communication skills.

But, there are still lessons to learn, even things that are only obvious once you actually learn them.

@ProfJbones @IsaacsHauntedB It doesn't even matter if the people above you are nice and considerate (most aren't), most apartments are built very cheaply, and you're going to hear the tiniest of noises loud and clear, especially if they have hardwood floors, or they drop something.

I don't know if we'll ever evolve enough to be able to solve such problems. The only way I can imagine that it'll stop is if we reach a place where we feel other people's well-being is more important than the microscopic little endorphin bump we get by sharing our opinion.

The entire dynamic has now changed, asymmetrically, and by even adding an innocent comment like "That's not very nice," your act may now in fact be more evil than even what the person did because of the damage you're doing.

...a palette full of the stuff. You may feel justified in saying "What an asshole."

Scenario B: The whole world gets a glimpse into Matt's personal life and millions of people get to say "What an asshole." and much worse, including doxxing and death threats.

It's heartbreaking.

This is what I mean when I say it's about scale:

Scenario A: Your Matt's neighbor. You go to your local grocery store to try and buy some hand sanitizer, but it's all sold out. On your way home, you catch a glimpse into your his garage and see...

...he (Matt Colvin) made an appearance in the documentary called 15 Minutes of Shame (which is about "Cancel Culture"). He breaks down crying at one point, saying "Someone was nice to me," in reference to an email he received, among the thousands of messages of hate.

Most people just don't care.

"You did something I don't like, so fuck you!"

Calling out bullshit in your personal life is one thing, but joining a mob to attack someone publicly can change everything.

Remember the guy that went viral for buying up hand sanitizer? Well...

I've always known that public-shaming is bad for one simple reason: scale.

Unfortunately, most people are not considerate enough to think about anything in the grand scheme of things, certainly not when they feel self-righteous.

I think people only really have 2 choices:

1. Be yourself and accept the consequences.
2. Betray yourself and reap the rewards.

There's always a 3rd option, right? Compartmentalize your life to the point where you're only real secretly.

Whatever you can accept and feel well.

I accept that by not playing the game of trying to fit in or make others fill comfortable by contradicting my true convictions, that I alienate others and myself from all sorts of things: jobs, friends, family, love, not being constantly judged as weird or creepy, etc.

Me personally? While I'm not perfect and will continue to improve myself (mainly my mind) until the day I die, I like myself. The average person does not like me. Whether they simply don't like me for who I really am, or just resent me for being myself, I accept that.

If you really want to improve your mind, your positivity, your overall well-being and betterment, it starts by being honest with yourself. And then either accept who you are or change it if you don't like it.

I don't think it's a mystery why so many games are being released with so many bugs nowadays.

...even if it is only a simulation.

So, how can we possibly know whether we're the very first reality, the so-called "real" reality, or one of infinite simulated realities after we reach that point? That's simulation theory, and many people that are far smarter than you or I believe that the likeliness that...

I wish I was real and I wish that it mattered, but I'm not and it doesn't.

More in-depth:

https://t.co/OsbPjJHiqf
Silly.

...of attention, but the wrong kind of attention. Maybe the brains around them said "Hey kid, you see those people over there. They're different, and we don't like them cause they're different." But, we all do it. We're all brains floating around, judging other brain's vehicles.

...there to "hand me that" or entertain me. It ain't no riddle; it's very simple to me. This isn't a complex understanding, which I had to somehow achieve; it's how I've always understand the world. Yet, to another brain, perhaps they weren't left alone. Maybe they got plenty...

No, of course not. Have you not been paying attention? I have the exact same brain as everyone else. I was just placed into a vehicle that was left alone a lot when young, which demanded more creativity, independence, and problem-solving, because their wasn't a bigger vehicle...

...their own vehicle-imposed biases that placed such incredible perspective stupidity into their brains. Because I'm able to step out of line and see the whole group of brains other than just the brain in front of me and the brain behind me, does that mean I have a special brain?

While the pain that some brains suffer due to racism, sexism, classism, etc. is absolutely real, and really does hurt the brain at a chemical level, the brains in which have prejudice toward other brains merely for the vehicle they were assigned, are limited by...

There are some molds for vehicles that are more common than others, making for an overall average person. Yet, these average people, despite having the exact same brains as all others, will either look up to or down to other vehicles for being "different."

But, ultimately, there's no such thing as achievement in this context. Two brains (which are exactly the same), one went into a very strong and tall vehicle that is capable of excelling at sports, and the very next one in line was placed in a vehicle that is unable to even move.

Some are sent into extreme circumstances that just barely meet the threshold of being able to be escaped from that it builds, whether good or bad (as perceived by other brains), great character. Great character can be used for "good" or "evil."

Some brains leave the factory and are placed in any number of circumstances. Some of those make for an easy life, a difficult life, and some that are completely doomed. Some brains are sent into circumstances so bad that no amount of determination will set them free.

The random look, size, color, genetic makeup of that vehicle, and then, wherever that vehicle is installed with whatever humans have been assigned to maintain it, all work together to create a lifetime of experiences, insecurities, biases, strengths, weaknesses, etc.

Nature vs Nurture?

I think it's both, and I tend to think of them both as external factors.

@ReddietoE That's the modern suicide hotline response, "Download our app."? I mean, there's a million different hotlines, right? Do most of them at least mean well, or are they like charities, mostly corrupt money-making scams?

These platitudes set up a false narrative that you even need to be beautiful or that you need someone in the first place to be happy. The message should be "Yeah, you're alone, but that's okay." If you think your loneliness can be solved by other people, you just don't get it.

Things like "It'll get better." or "I'm sure someone will miss you." or "There's someone out there for everyone." or "You're beautiful." None of these things are true for *everyone*. Some people are ugly, some people are unpleasant to be around, some people are truly alone.

I've had some people in my life commit suicide now, as I'm sure plenty of you have too. I can only imagine the stupid, condescending, untrue platitudes that suicide hotline reps read off of scripts to people.

I think things like platitudes and suicide hotlines and even religion can be dangerous for mental health and even backfire. I'm not saying that any of these things can't be good, but so long as you have an honest and healthy foundation and you're not using them as a crutch. https://t.co/BI2Yu5rob4
@BillBodden That's not to say that there's anything wrong with having people or many people in your life, but depending on others for survival, validation, etc. isn't healthy. End of rant. üíõ

@BillBodden The message that there's someone for everyone for example, sets up the false narrative that there even needs to be someone for everyone. There isn't. Some people are alone, and there's nothing wrong with that. It's better to be strong enough to be alone than to require others.

Assuming you can't have both, which would you rather have?
Do you put pants on just to step onto your front porch?

Somehow, it's enough; it's a choice.

I don't know if it takes an incredible amount of strength and discipline (or delusion) to make that choice, or if it's a choice that's hidden in plain sight, that people just can't see most of the time, but it's there.

I think that's the tragedy of most people. The idea that it's better to burn out than fade away. They need more. I don't really have friends anymore, I don't have love, I don't have my own house, I don't even have pets, but I have a houseplant that I'm learning how to keep alive.
I think a little delusion is actually helpful when it comes to mental health. It's your brain's best defense mechanism after all. I choose simple things over alcohol or drugs or suicide.

I know it sounds stupid. In terms of first-world countries at least, my life on paper is objectively bad (to most), but it's all superficial really. I choose to be happy with what I have and I let small things bring me joy, like my new salt and pepper grinders or a houseplant.

Ya know, within reason, I don't think delusion is all bad.

Believe me, I'm hyper self-aware, and I admit all my flaws.

However, there's something to the idea that you can't force the world to be better and you can't force people to be better, but you can still choose to smile. https://t.co/aYkcqWh2ey
